column5: When I was first diagnosed with depression I was in a funk so bad I couldn‚Äôt get out of bed for three weeks.  I wanted to not exist and had no desire to do anything.  Hang in there, and don‚Äôt give up hope.

This is a common side effect of depression.  I deal with it a lot.  Fortunately I found enough help with my chemical depression that I now get out of bed daily by 8am and I usually enjoy it.  It‚Äôs only taken 20 years of therapy and experimenting to find what works.

It takes time to draw that line and for me, it took years of therapy.  Look into ACT and CBT therapy.  

Trying to deal with mental illness is like trying to heal a broken leg while still walking on it.  It‚Äôs not easy and it can be very painful.  

Don‚Äôt give up hope.  Ultimately, you decide what you are going to do, so separate ‚Äúyou‚Äù from your thoughts, stick to your values, and keep on moving in a positive direction.
I‚Äôve had thoughts like this before.  Remember that you are not your thoughts.  Thoughts happen.  You can‚Äôt prevent having them, but you can prevent acting on them.

Having lived with depression for 30+ years, I believe that yes you can be happy.  There are a lot of expectations and baggage that need to be dropped to get there, depending on where your depression comes from.  I get happier every day, but I still have times I want to die.
You don‚Äôt need to fish for compliments, they should be jumping into the boat!

I used to view life like this.  The universe doesn‚Äôt care enough about any of us to do things to us.  Shit happens to all of us.  You just have to learn to let go of the feeling that everything is trying to tear you down and decide that you just see obstacles that you have to walk around.  You can still do what you wanted to do, you just have to do things differently than you expected.  I believe in you and know you can do it!

I have been recovering from scrupulosity since I was a teen.  I feared god like no other and always thought a bigger punishments was around the corner.  After leaving the cult of mormonism and becoming agnostic I realized I was conditioned to always expect bad things to happen so I would feel a need to run back to the church.  
Finding that clarity helped me realize that I was just a random guy and there wasn‚Äôt someone trying to punish me, things just happen.  Now I don‚Äôt feel suspicious very often but when things are all going smoothly I do feel the law of averages is going to kick in and the roller coaster is about to go the other direction.

Logan is a great place for introverts and outdoorsy people.  Most of the Mormons are friendly and kind.  As far as culture goes, It‚Äôs got a lot of Mormon culture like musical theatre and choir/band performances, but there is really only one bar and not much else.  Sunday‚Äôs are wonderfully not busy downtown or anywhere other than churches.  If I‚Äôm not mistaken Logan also keeps getting awards for being one of the safest place to live in the US.

When my shelf was breaking I decided to pray and ask for confirmation.  I felt the spirit tell me to leave because it wasn‚Äôt true.  It was the same feeling I had felt when I believed.  I told that to my TBM wife and she had no response.  So it works both ways!  üòÇ
Food pantry on main will hook them up

There is a growing exmormon crowd here, and from your comments it seems you would fit right in.  I was a Mormon student at USU a decade or so back and it sounds like you have it pegged.  Now as an exmormon, I can relate to your view much better and would have had similar experiences, especially with dating.  Hang in there and if you ever need someone to grab a coffee with let me know.
The engineering program has a great reputation.  I vote in favor of USU. üòÉ

Sometimes it helps to just allow it.  Don‚Äôt fight it, just let it be.  What would you like to be doing or thinking about?  Focus on that, but don‚Äôt get angry that it isn‚Äôt easy, just let the other thoughts exist and know it isn‚Äôt you.  It will all work out.  Hang in there, you aren‚Äôt alone.
I don‚Äôt know what it is but every therapist I‚Äôve been to has had horrible office staff.  They never treat people well and are not sensitive to what you are going through.  I‚Äôm sorry.

You‚Äôre not silly and not alone.  I look ‚Äònormal‚Äô and get shit for not being disabled when I‚Äôm parking in the handicapped stalls, but they don‚Äôt have to feel the crazy pain in every step and I try to be forgiving but I just get furious that people don‚Äôt believe me.  Sometimes I feel like printing out my MRI and putting text over it ‚ÄúFuck you!‚Äù
You seem to have a disability that prevents you from doing what an able bodied human can, so I say yes.  Welcome to the club, don‚Äôt forget to pay your membership dues. üòÇ
If you have to ask, you must not be normal. üòú
I‚Äôve had this problem all my life.  You are definitely not alone.
You are not alone.  When my mind is in a funk, I hate everyone and everything.
There are meds specifically for anxiety. E.g. Xanax.

psychologist does talk therapy and psychiatrist does meds. They usually work in combination because depression and anxiety come from both chemical imbalance and cognitive issues.  I‚Äôve needed both, but currently only use meds and do my own self talk therapy since I‚Äôve been dealing with this for 20+ years.

You are welcome for the support! I didn‚Äôt have this opportunity back when I was first diagnosed so I try to lurk here and help where I can.  It‚Äôs nice to know you are not alone. üôÇ

I‚Äôve struggled with this my whole life, but I‚Äôve gotten better at handling stress.  From what I understand, the digestive system has a second brain (enteric nervous system) and the two brains don‚Äôt always communicate well.  I was taking prescription strength antacids at 8 years of age and went to the hospital 3 different times in my youth from this issue.  Just knowing about the two brains not communicating well and using CBT and ACT therapy help me cope.  I still end up taking anxiety meds when I can‚Äôt keep it at bay, but it‚Äôs much better than it used to be.
Can‚Äôt provide an official diagnosis but it sounds like my OCD.  I have used meds, ACT, and CBT therapy.  Hang in there.
I don‚Äôt know what I can do, but I‚Äôm listening.

Anger is a symptom of depression.  I‚Äôve been dealing with it for over 20 years now.  As you work through therapy and learn and understand your specific issues, it will get better.  My anger has stemmed from unrealistic expectations, which is a common source of depression.  I also have chemical depression that is only relieved by medication.  It‚Äôs challenging, but hang on.

I worked at the university IT service desk and took on the development without experience because no one else wanted to do it.  I learned on my own for the most part and built what was needed.  After getting two years of experience I started getting offers for other jobs.  The university wanted to add more developers but they were too expensive.  So they hired inexperienced students who were interested.  After 5 years of experience the university wouldn‚Äôt keep up with my value so I took a new job and they continued to hire inexperienced people they could train.

Because developers with experience are in high demand, a lot of universities and other non-profits will hire inexperienced SN devs to train them up and get cheaper labor.  You should look into that.  It‚Äôs where I got my start.
I‚Äôve had a lot of the same feelings.  I‚Äôm sorry you are going through it.  The brain is a big Pain In The Ass.  You aren‚Äôt bad, just human.
Look up ‚Äúgrounding‚Äù techniques.  Anxiety builds up in a cycle and doesn‚Äôt seem to stop.  Grounding really helps me with my anxiety.

Anyone with anxiety and depression goes through it and if nothing else, just know you are not alone.  I‚Äôm what I would consider high functioning but I‚Äôve been at the point of not being able to leave the house.  A metaphor that helps me is to imagine that a pebble can look like a boulder if you hold it close to your eye, so separate yourself from the problems and try to step back and realize that things will get better.  
You can do this.  
I believe in you.
I don‚Äôt appreciate getting chastised for struggling with my mental health, but I‚Äôm sure I just don‚Äôt understand exactly what you are saying.  That being said...thanks for the support.

I‚Äôve been struggling since I was 12 years old.  At my worst, I laid in bed for weeks at a time and could not get out of the house.  Now I‚Äôm usually able to get out of my funk in a few hours.  Days like today are not as frequent, but they suck.  On the inside I love life and want to live, but the depression grabs hold and seems to think it owns me.
Thanks for being there!  Your response was just what I needed.
Thank you
